docs.snippet: 5 A.M. (TCM) 8 1/2 (1963) In this dazzling Freudian mosaic from Fellini, Marcello Mastroianni plays an Italian film director who retreats from the demands of moviemaking by reminiscing about his life and loves, and in the process finds inspiration...
docs.lead_paragraph: 5 A.M. (TCM) 8 1/2 (1963) In this dazzling Freudian mosaic from Fellini, Marcello Mastroianni plays an Italian film director who retreats from the demands of moviemaking by reminiscing about his life and loves, and in the process finds inspiration for his next project. Fellini received Oscar nominations for best director and, with his colleagues Ennio Flaiano, Tullio Pinelli and Brunello Rondi, best screenplay. The movie won for best foreign-language film and Piero Gherardi for best costume design. In ''The Bicycle Thief'' (1948), at 7:30, a laborer (Lamberto Maggiorani) and his young son (Enzo Staiola, above right, with Mr. Maggiorani) search for the stolen bicycle that the man desperately needs back to keep his new job. Vittorio De Sica directed this classic neo-realist study of poverty in postwar Rome. 1 P.M. (HBO2) VALENTINE'S DAY (2010) Ashton Kutcher, playing a Los Angeles florist privy to any number of botched romantic situations, leads a cast in this comedy from Garry Marshall, which includes Jessica Alba, Kathy Bates, Jessica Biel , Bradley Cooper, Eric Dane, Patrick Dempsey, Hector Elizondo, Jamie Foxx, Jennifer Garner, Anne Hathaway, Julia Roberts and others. Writing for The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said the best thing about the film ''is that it makes you appreciate and long for the breeziness, acting and basic competency -- the decent lighting, focused cameras and choreographed action -- of 'Love Actually,' the ingratiating British movie it transparently and ineptly rips off.''

docs.snippet: Between the Grammys, Whitney Houston  and Jeremy Lin, the Bagger is nearly overwhelmed by blogworthy topics. (And realtalk: we're still trying to get over Madge and world peace, not to mention Metta World Peace.)     Let's look to the British to s...
docs.lead_paragraph: Between the Grammys, Whitney Houston and Jeremy Lin, the Bagger is nearly overwhelmed by blogworthy topics. (And realtalk: we're still trying to get over Madge and world peace, not to mention Metta World Peace.) Let's look to the British to set us straight: the Baftas, the British version of the Oscars, were handed out on Sunday, and they could be a preview of our own big movie night. ''The Artist'' swept, winning seven awards, including best picture, director, screenplay, composer, costumes and best actor for Jean Dujardin. (Best screenplay is especially notable for a film with almost no dialogue.)
docs.abstract: Seven Baftas, the British version of the Oscars, are awarded to The Artist, which has also been nominated for several Academy Awards. (M)ÿ

headline.main: Big Win for 'The Artist' In British Film Awards

docs.snippet: The Grammy Awards telecast on CBS smashed every recent ratings record Sunday night, not just for the music awards show but for any awards broadcast, fueled by keen interest in how the show would pay tribute to Whitney Houston, who had died the day...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Grammy Awards telecast on CBS smashed every recent ratings record Sunday night, not just for the music awards show but for any awards broadcast, fueled by keen interest in how the show would pay tribute to Whitney Houston, who had died the day before. For its full duration - the show ended out of prime time at 11:33 p.m. in the East - the Grammys attracted 39.9 million viewers, making it the most-watched nonsports program of the television season.
docs.abstract: Grammy Awards telecast breaks every recent ratings record for that show and for any awards broadcast. Photo (M)2

headline.main: Grammy Awards Show Hits a Ratings High Note
